Award.AwardTitle: Transcription and Translation in a Uniquely Compartmentalized Bacterial Cell

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
Intellectual Merit
Bacteria are usually considered to be simple life forms, but some species are known to possess compartments within their cells. While some compartments serve to separate physiological processes from the rest of the cell, the function of others is undetermined. The significance of membrane-bound compartments containing genomic DNA (superficially resembling eukaryotic nuclei) is particularly elusive. Planctomycete bacteria have an unusual cell plan, with the genomic DNA and ribosomes restricted to one of two cellular compartments. Even greater complexity is found in the planctomycete Gemmata obscuriglobus, which possesses an additional network of double-layered membranes surrounding the genomic DNA. The goal of this project is to determine whether the additional G. obscuriglobus membrane network is functionally equivalent to the eukaryotic nuclear membrane. The main research focus is the potential uncoupling of transcription and translation (a hallmark of eukaryotic cell biology, but not known to occur in Bacteria), and identification of membrane transport mechanisms. The experimental approach involves localization and characterization of proteins in the different cell compartments, using electron and fluorescence microscopy, as well as physical separation of the compartments. The project provides a unique opportunity to explore an apparent exception to the rule of coupled bacterial transcription and translation, and determine whether this complex microbial cell organization can be used to support models of eukaryotic cell evolution.

Broader Impacts
The project will promote teaching, training, and learning through classroom instruction, research training (one postdoctoral fellow, one graduate student, two undergraduate researchers), and an initiative for high school teachers. Teachers will participate in research apprenticeships and workshops, leading to the implementation of new curriculum in their classrooms. The project will therefore contribute to future science and technology capabilities in the United States.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit. Bacteria are usually considered to be simple life forms, but some species have more complicated cellular organization, for unknown reasons. The significance of complex internal membranes in members of a bacterial group called the Planctomycetes has been particularly elusive. In one particular planctomycete species, Gemmata obscuriglobus, the membranes appear to almost surround the genomic DNA, superficially resembling the nuclear membrane that encloses the DNA in eukaryotic species (plants and animals). The goal of this project was to determine whether the G. obscuriglobus membrane network is functionally equivalent to the eukaryotic nuclear membrane, by physically separating transcription (copying of the DNA code into an RNA message) and translation (converting the RNA message into a protein sequence). These processes are always separate in eukaryotic cells, but usually coupled in bacterial cells (because of the lack of nuclear membrane). Our experimental approach involved localization of protein "markers" for transcription and translation in the different regions of the cell, using electron and fluorescence microscopy. We found that while, as expected, transcription occurred only close to the DNA, active translation was detected throughout the cell, including regions that were quite distant from the DNA. We therefore obtained evidence that at least some translation is spatially separated from transcription in G. obscuriglobus, as in eukaryotes. Although it is tempting to speculate that the unusual internal membranes provide a physical barrier to coupling of transcription and translation, we have no direct evidence for this, and in fact there is some spatial separation of these processes in "simple" model organism bacteria such as Escherichia coli. Nevertheless, our work raises the possibility that the membranes may have this role (a hypothesis for future testing), and may also provide a useful context for understanding how ancient eukaryotic cells evolved more complex organization and decoupling of transcription and translation.

In additional work supported by this award, we have also begun to investigate the membrane composition of G. obscuriglobus.  This species, and all other planctomycetes, have long been thought to possess a unique cell plan, in which the internal membranes discussed above are additional to the usual cytoplasmic membrane. Planctomycetes were also thought to lack the typical Gram-negative outer membrane (OM). However, signature components of an OM had been predicted by recent genomic analysis. We tested this prediction by attempting to isolate and characterize lipopolysaccharide (LPS), one of these components. We obtained direct evidence for LPS, using analytical chemistry approaches, and also detected a previously unknown polyunsaturated fatty acid. Our confirmation of LPS, and by implication an OM, in G. obscuriglobus, raises the possibility that other planctomycetes possess an OM. Pursuit of this question will shed more light on what is emerging as a planctomycete variation on the Gram-negative cell plan, contributing to our understanding of the diversity of bacterial cellular forms.
